pullRequest.body:
In the proof of `wellFounded_lt_exact_sequence`, it is implicitly shown that `fun x : Î± â†¦ (x âŠ“ z, x âŠ” z)` is StrictMono in a modular lattice, with the lexicographic order on `Î± Ã— Î±`. Here we show the stronger result with `Î± Ã— Î±` equipped with the product order, and golf the proof.

If `G` is not an abelian group, then `Î± = Subgroup G` is not necessarily a modular lattice. However, if `z` is a normal subgroup, the result still holds true. We prove a closely related result `strictMono_comap_prod_map` which replaces `inf` with `comap` and `sup` with `map`, so it concerns a function to `Subgroup z Ã— Subgroup (G â§¸ z)` instead. The same result for submodules immediately implies that Noetherian/Artinian are closed under extensions, which is proven in #17425 using `wellFounded_lt/gt_exact_sequence`.

If `z` is not even normal, the function to `Subgroup z Ã— Set (G â§¸ z)` is still StrictMono.

---

ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11214776470/job/31170559148)
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11214776470/job/31170558914)
The target type of this function is a mixed of Subgroup and Set, and I feel it would be better that it be homogeneous.
otherwise, this is good to me.

I could make the target `Set s Ã— Set (Î± â§¸ s)` but I think the current version is potentially more useful, because e.g. if `s` is infinite then `Set s` isn't well-founded either way, but `Subgroup s` may well be.
Why not making it `Subgroup s Ã— Subgroup (Î± â§¸ s)` ?
If `s` is normal, sure. And it is done in GroupTheory/QuotientGroup/Basic.lean.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: `fun x â†¦ (x âŠ“ z, x âŠ” z)` is StrictMono in ModularLattice
